| Stage | Coal | Nuclear |

## How a “rare” nuclear accident can dominate the **average** death‑rate of nuclear power  
*(i.e., how Chernobyl or Fukushima end up inside the 0.04 – 0.07 deaths / TWh figure)*  

### 1. The basic arithmetic that underlies the life‑cycle metric  

The **life‑cycle death‑rate** for a technology is calculated as  

\[
\boxed{\text{Deaths per TWh}= \frac{\displaystyle\sum\text{(all attributable deaths)}}{\displaystyle\sum\text{(electricity generated over the same period)}}}
\]

*The numerator* = all deaths that can be reasonably linked to the technology (occupational, accident‑related, long‑term health impacts).  
*The denominator* = the cumulative electricity that the technology has produced **over the same time‑span** (usually from the start of commercial operation to the most recent year for which data exist).

Because the denominator is huge—**tens of thousands of terawatt‑hours** for nuclear—**even a few hundred extra deaths make only a tiny change** in the ratio.
